articles.headline: Young Adults Make Gains in Health Insurance Coverage
articles.snippet: Young adults, long the group most likely to be uninsured, are gaining health coverage faster than expected since the 2010 health law began allowing parents to cover them as dependents on family policies.
articles.abstract: Young adults, long the group most likely to be uninsured, are gaining health coverage faster than expected since the 2010 health law began allowing parents to cover them as dependents on family policies.
articles.lead_paragraph: Young adults, long the group most likely to be uninsured, are gaining health coverage faster than expected since the 2010 health law began allowing parents to cover them as dependents on family policies.

articles.headline: Fed Will Shift Debt Holdings to Lift Growth
articles.snippet: The Federal Reserve is shifting $400 billion from short- to long-term Treasury securities to push interest rates down and encourage companies to borrow and spend.
articles.abstract: The Federal Reserve is shifting $400 billion from short- to long-term Treasury securities to push interest rates down and encourage companies to borrow and spend.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve announced an unconventional plan on Wednesday to reduce borrowing costs for businesses and consumers, trying once more to spur economic growth despite urgings from Republicans that it refrain from any expansion of its stimulus program.

articles.headline: No Cards, No Cash. Just a Phone.
articles.snippet: Google Wallet, which runs only on Sprint’s Google Nexus S, lets consumers charge purchases with a tap of their phone at the cash register.
articles.abstract: Google Wallet, which runs only on Sprint’s Google Nexus S, lets consumers charge purchases with a tap of their phone at the cash register.
articles.lead_paragraph: Plenty of companies would love to get their hands on our wallets. But Google wants to go one step further: it wants to be our wallets.

articles.headline: House Rebukes G.O.P. Leaders Over Spending
articles.snippet: House Republicans suffered a surprising setback when the House rejected their version of a stopgap spending bill, leaving unclear how Congress will keep the government open and aid natural disaster victims.
articles.abstract: House Republicans suffered a surprising setback when the House rejected their version of a stopgap spending bill, leaving unclear how Congress will keep the government open and aid natural disaster victims.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — House Republican leaders suffered a surprising setback on Wednesday when the House rejected their version of a stopgap spending bill, leaving unclear how Congress will provide money to keep the government open after Sept. 30 and aid victims of a string of costly recent natural disasters.
articles.byline: By Robert Pear and Jennifer Steinhauer

articles.headline: Produce Importer in Food Safety Fight
articles.snippet: Del Monte Fresh Produce has accused federal and state regulators of bullying and overreaching in a case involving contaminated melons.
articles.abstract: Del Monte Fresh Produce has accused federal and state regulators of bullying and overreaching in a case involving contaminated melons.
articles.lead_paragraph: When health investigators identified imported cantaloupes as the source of a salmonella outbreak early this year, the importer agreed to a recall. But now that company, Del Monte Fresh Produce, is trying to block additional restrictions on melon imports, setting off an unusually public battle between the produce industry and food safety regulators.

articles.headline: Taking a Stand, and Shedding Arafat’s Shadow
articles.snippet: Will this moment of unparalleled prestige for President Mahmoud Abbas, the Palestinian leader, produce concrete results or a new and more dangerous set of risks?
articles.abstract: Will this moment of unparalleled prestige for President Mahmoud Abbas, the Palestinian leader, produce concrete results or a new and more dangerous set of risks?
articles.lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — At the baronial Morgan Library in Midtown Manhattan the other night, President Mahmoud Abbas, the Palestinian leader, stood quietly along the edge of a diplomatic reception, avoiding the animated gossip and flowing Champagne.
articles.byline: By Neil MacFarquhar and Ethan Bronner

articles.headline: Voting to Hire a Chief Without Meeting Him
articles.snippet: Hewlett-Packard’s trouble with its chief executive lies with its board, which is rife with animosities, suspicion, distrust and personal ambition.
articles.abstract: Hewlett-Packard’s trouble with its chief executive lies with its board, which is rife with animosities, suspicion, distrust and personal ambition.
articles.lead_paragraph: The mystery isn’t why Hewlett-Packard is likely to part ways with its chief executive, Léo Apotheker, after just a year in the job. It’s why he was hired in the first place.

articles.headline: Obama Rebuffed as Palestinians Pursue U.N. Seat
articles.snippet: An extraordinary tableau at the United Nations underscored that the United States may have to share, or even cede, its decades-long role as the architect of Middle East peacemaking.
articles.abstract: An extraordinary tableau at the United Nations underscored that the United States may have to share, or even cede, its decades-long role as the architect of Middle East peacemaking.
articles.lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — A last-ditch American effort to head off a Palestinian bid for membership in the United Nations faltered. President Obama tried to qualify his own call, just a year ago, for a Palestinian state. And President Nicolas Sarkozy of France stepped forcefully into the void, with a proposal that pointedly repudiated Mr. Obama’s approach.
articles.byline: By Helene Cooper and Steven Lee Myers

articles.headline: Stocks Decline a Day After Fed Sets Latest Stimulus Measure
articles.snippet: Investor pessimism about the outlook for the United States and European economies was deepened by weak data for the euro zone and a grim assessment from the Federal Reserve.
articles.abstract: Investor pessimism about the outlook for the United States and European economies was deepened by weak data for the euro zone and a grim assessment from the Federal Reserve.
articles.lead_paragraph: A day after the Federal Reserve announced another measure to bolster the economy, world financial markets tumbled Thursday on fears that governments around the globe collectively still were not doing enough to stimulate growth.
articles.byline: By Graham Bowley and Christine Hauser
